title: Soprano Laura Wright battles arthritis pain through pregnancy
text:

There’s a dark humour in the London home of soprano Laura Wright and her husband, Harry Rowland.

“We joke we have one working pair of knees between us,” laughs the 29-year-old who has suffered from arthritis in her right knee since she was a child.

Harry, 32, a professional rugby player turned personal trainer, ­developed the condition in his left knee after an injury five years ago.

You might not know Laura’s name, but you’re bound to have heard her break into song – either in her post as the official anthem singer for the RFU, at each Invictus Games opening ceremony, or when she performed for the Queen at the Diamond Jubilee.

(Image: PR Pic)

Laura was just nine and on holiday with her family in Aldeburgh, Suffolk, when she first experienced pain in her knee.

“I went for a run by the sea with dad and remember feeling a discomfort that got progressively worse over a few days until it was quite clear something was very wrong,” she explains.

“We went to the GP who sent us to hospital for tests.

"My joint swelled so I needed several operations to drain the fluid.

"I spent the time in hospital clenching my knee to my chest because it was so painful, so they decided to put it in plaster to keep it straight while they figured out what was wrong.”

The cast meant that Laura returned to school in ­Framlingham, Suffolk, after the summer in a wheelchair.

“That had its frustrations because I wasn’t able to run around with my friends, but at the same time I was so young a lot of it went over my head.

"I was having fun being pushed around by my three older brothers. The whole thing was a huge concern for my parents though – there was a point they were told I might not walk again.”

Because of her age – the majority of arthritis sufferers are over 40 – doctors struggled to diagnose Laura’s condition and she was pumped with antibiotics to clear the infection.

“Nothing they tried was working,” says Laura.

“Even once I was back at school I would have to take nine or 10 pills a day.

"It was almost 18 months before they worked out I had septic arthritis, caused by a strain of bacteria that infects the joint. They hadn’t thought of it because it was unusual to happen at such a young age.

“Finally, they were able to give me the correct medication but it had taken so long to get there I was left with permanent arthritis in my knee.

"All the ­antibiotics had wiped my immune system as well. It still isn't very strong now.”

Laura, who is now eight months pregnant with her first child, has always been determined the condition wouldn’t hold her back.

She still has pain in her right knee, particularly if she “overdoes it”, but she ran the London Marathon in April shortly after she discovered she was ­pregnant.

“My knee really suffered for that, but usually I only need occasional over-the-counter pain relief, nothing special,” she explains.

“I was so poorly when I was young that I feel lucky to be able to move and enjoy sport.

"I know how ­important it is to my mental health, so I’d rather move and get pain and endorphins from exercising than not.

“I love CrossFit, but while I’ve been pregnant I’ve been doing a lot more swimming.”

And, of course, being able to support Harry through his own arthritis journey has been cathartic for both of them.

“Undoubtedly there is a process that anyone having a setback goes through – psychologically it’s challenging – so it was nice to be able to help him,” she says.

(Image: Can Nguyen/REX/Shutterstock)

It’s one of the reasons Laura is supporting Versus Arthritis’ #PainNoFilter social media campaign.

“We are all guilty of thinking we can’t talk about our pain because there are others experiencing worse.

“Arthritis is often dismissed as it’s invisible, so having open conversations is important.

"We need to get people talking to help everyone find ways to deal with their pain without letting it define us.”
description: EXCLUSIVE: Laura, 29, was just nine when she first started experiencing symptoms of arthritis and quickly needed a wheelchair
